title: Research in Biological Chemistry
description: Individual research under the supervision of a professor.

title: Research in Biological Chemistry

title: Research in Biological Chemistry for First-Year Students
description: Independent research within the laboratories of graduate training faculty in the Department of Biological Chemistry for first-year Ph.D. students.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 3 times.

title: Laboratory Seminar Series
description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

title: Laboratory Seminar Series
description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

title: Laboratory Seminar Series
description: Study within a laboratory group including research and journal presentations.

title: Current Topics in Cancer Genomics
description: Literature-based discussion of molecular principles in genetics and functional genomics, with focus on cancer and stem cell biology.
repeatability: May be taken for credit 2 times.

title: Medical Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: Covers the following topics from a biomedical perspective: protein and nucleic acid biochemistry, carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, purines and pyrimidines, genome structure, molecular mechanisms of development, and signal transduction.

title: Mouse Developmental Genetics
description: Introduction to using the mouse in contemporary biomedical research. The biology and development of the laboratory mouse, methods for manipulation of the mouse genome and embryos, and examples of application of these methods to understand mammalian development and homeostasis.

title: Human Evolution and Behavior
description: Covers theories and empirical research concerning the evolutionary origins of human behaviors and their variations. An interdisciplinary course emphasizing both evolutionary psychology (e.g., mating strategies, kinship, and parenting) and molecular evolution (i.e., evolution of genes for various behaviors).

title: Epigenetics in Health and Disease
description: Focuses on the role of chromatin/nuclear structure organization (histone and DNA modification, chromatin remodeling, higher order chromatin structure and nuclear organization) on gene regulation, DNA replication and repair, relevant to development, metabolism, learning and memory, and human disease.
prerequisite: MOL BIO 203 or MOL BIO 204 or NEURBIO 206

title: Research Seminar
description: Student research-based colloquium covering current topics in gene organization and expression, cell cycle and differentiation, DNA repair, checkpoint control, and the physical, chemical, and biological properties of macromolecules. Students are encouraged to read critically and analyze recent literature.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.

title: Scientific Communication
description: Small group meetings for graduate students to practice scientific writing, debate, and presentation skills.
repeatability: May be repeated for credit unlimited times.
